availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

body.p: Louisville, Kentucky workhouse. Organized in 1832 to house male and female petty criminals, the poor, "those of bad repute," and those with infectious diseases. Managed by a committee of three trustees and a superintendent, with daily operations overseen by an elected keeper. Superintendent(s): Trustee(s): Keeper(s): M. G. Holmes (1861).

ab.bibl:
"Board of Aldermen: Joint Session," Courier-Journal (Louisville, KY), October 19, 1861, p. 1.
Charter of the City of Louisville, Ky. (Louisville: L. A. Civill, Printer, 1862), 332-36.
"Louisville City Workhouse," Kentucky Historic Institutions, accessed January 26, 2022, https://kyhi.org/louisville-city-workhouse/.
Morton O. Childress, Louisville Division of Police History and Personnel (Paducah, KY: Turner Publishing Company, 2005), 62.
Gary Falk, Louisville Remembered (Charleston, SC: The History Press, 2009) 112-13.
